32.text: The tenement is located in the northern part of the Rocklea Dome in the South Pilbara

33.text: Basin covering well exposed parts of the Fortescue Group.  The Fortescue Group

34.text: contains basaltic komatiite flows including olivine cumulate-rich channel facies rocks

35.text: within the Pyradie Formation as well as high MgO-parented differentiated sills within

36.text: both the Pyradie Formation and underlying Boongal and Hardey Formations.  These

37.text: sills are co-genetic with the Pyradie Formation basaltic komatiite flows and are

38.text: potential sub-volcanic, flow-through chambers to the overlying komatiitic volcanics.

39.text: Both the sills and the channel facies rocks of the basaltic komatiite sequence are

40.text: considered prospective for magmatic Ni-Cu-PGE sulphide mineralisation.

45.text: Tenement E47/1206 was granted on 23 January 2006.  Full tenement details are shown

46.text: in Table 1.  The tenement is located in the northern part of the Rocklea Dome (Figure

47.text: 1).  The tenement is somewhat isolated with no road or track access although a poorly

48.text: used track runs close to the tenement’s western boundary.  Much of the area is rugged

49.text: and is only accessible by foot.

text:
INTRODUCTION 
 The tenement is located in the northern part of the Rocklea Dome in the South Pilbara 
 Basin covering well exposed parts of the Fortescue Group.  The Fortescue Group 
 contains basaltic komatiite flows including olivine cumulate-rich channel facies rocks 
 within the Pyradie Formation as well as high MgO-parented differentiated sills within 
 both the Pyradie Formation and underlying Boongal and Hardey Formations.  These 
 sills are co-genetic with the Pyradie Formation basaltic komatiite flows and are 
 potential sub-volcanic, flow-through chambers to the overlying komatiitic volcanics.  
 Both the sills and the channel facies rocks of the basaltic komatiite sequence are 
 considered prospective for magmatic Ni-Cu-PGE sulphide mineralisation. 
 TENEMENT STATUS, LOCATION AND ACCESS 
 Tenement E47/1206 was granted on 23 January 2006.  Full tenement details are shown 
 in Table 1.  The tenement is located in the northern part of the Rocklea Dome (Figure 
 1).  The tenement is somewhat isolated with no road or track access although a poorly 
 used track runs close to the tenement’s western boundary.  Much of the area is rugged 
 and is only accessible by foot.

18.text: Little work has been undertaken on the tenement as it has been under application.

19.text: Limited rock chip sampling of the most MgO-rich looking rocks has located

20.text: ultramafic rocks with 14-16% MgO and 925-1410 ppm Cr (hydrous) that are likely to

21.text: have been  pyroxenitic in character derived from basaltic komatiite magma.  However

24.text: It is recommended that the Pyradie Formation within the tenement be mapped.  Also

25.text: previous exploration undertaken within the Hardy Formation within the tenement

26.text: should be reviewed with the aim of assessing the potential of the highly magnetic sill

27.text: located along the contact between the Hardy and Boongal Formations.

text:
Little work has been undertaken on the tenement as it has been under application.  
 Limited rock chip sampling of the most MgO-rich looking rocks has located 
 ultramafic rocks with 14-16% MgO and 925-1410 ppm Cr (hydrous) that are likely to 
 have been  pyroxenitic in character derived from basaltic komatiite magma.  However 
 no olivine-rich rocks were encountered. 
 It is recommended that the Pyradie Formation within the tenement be mapped.  Also 
 previous exploration undertaken within the Hardy Formation within the tenement 
 should be reviewed with the aim of assessing the potential of the highly magnetic sill 
 located along the contact between the Hardy and Boongal Formations.

13.text: C)  Layered ultramafic-mafic sill.  Layered mafic and ultramafic-mafic sills occur

14.text: mainly in the Hardey and Pyradie Formations.  Sills range from 30 to 350 m

15.text: thick and have strike extents up to 20 km and perhaps greater.  Most sills

16.text: appear to consist of a single differentiated unit consisting of a relatively thin

17.text: basal pyroxenitic zone grading upwards into an upper zone of gabbro or

18.text: dolerite or both.  In a sill mapped by Cowley (1979) the basal pyroxenite zone

19.text: is the same thickness as the overlying mafic zone (Figure 5) strongly

20.text: suggesting that this sill also acted as a flow-through chamber for Pyradie

21.text: magma.  The geographic distribution of the layered sills broadly mirrors that

22.text: of the basaltic komatiite flows within the Pyradie Formation, further

23.text: suggesting that the sills acted as subvolcanic feeder chambers to the overlying

61.text: Basal marginal zone and augite cumulate

68.text: Figure 2.  Lithological profile through basaltic komatiite flow, Rocklea Dome.

text:
that it was a flow-through chamber for Pyradie magma.  Indeed Cowley 
 (1979) has mapped a dyke leading upwards from the top of this sill strongly 
 indicating that it did indeed act as a flow-through chamber. 
 C)  Layered ultramafic-mafic sill.  Layered mafic and ultramafic-mafic sills occur 
 mainly in the Hardey and Pyradie Formations.  Sills range from 30 to 350 m 
 thick and have strike extents up to 20 km and perhaps greater.  Most sills 
 appear to consist of a single differentiated unit consisting of a relatively thin 
 basal pyroxenitic zone grading upwards into an upper zone of gabbro or 
 dolerite or both.  In a sill mapped by Cowley (1979) the basal pyroxenite zone 
 is the same thickness as the overlying mafic zone (Figure 5) strongly 
 suggesting that this sill also acted as a flow-through chamber for Pyradie 
 magma.  The geographic distribution of the layered sills broadly mirrors that 
 of the basaltic komatiite flows within the Pyradie Formation, further 
 suggesting that the sills acted as subvolcanic feeder chambers to the overlying 
 extrusive flows (Cowley, 1979; Bright, 1985; Meakins, 1990).

48.text: Safety protocols in accordance with AusQuest’s Occupational Health and Safety

49.text: Management System were implemented during exploration activities throughout the

50.text: reporting year.  No significant incidents or accidents were reported.

text:
Safety protocols in accordance with AusQuest’s Occupational Health and Safety 
 Management System were implemented during exploration activities throughout the 
 reporting year.  No significant incidents or accidents were reported.

17.text: As shown on the 1:100 000 scale Rocklea geology map (Figure 6) the Pyradie

18.text: Formation extends east-west through the centre of the tenement.  Metakomatiitic

19.text: ultramafic rocks comprised of olivine-rich cumulates are shown within the Pyradie

20.text: extending from the west to the Beasley River in the centre of the tenement.  This

21.text: distribution of ultramafic rocks is supported by aeromagnetics (Figure 7).

text:
As shown on the 1:100 000 scale Rocklea geology map (Figure 6) the Pyradie 
 Formation extends east-west through the centre of the tenement.  Metakomatiitic 
 ultramafic rocks comprised of olivine-rich cumulates are shown within the Pyradie 
 extending from the west to the Beasley River in the centre of the tenement.  This 
 distribution of ultramafic rocks is supported by aeromagnetics (Figure 7).

23.text: Clearly, however, other magnetic units are present within the sequence.  The dolerite

24.text: sill shown on the contact between the Hardy and Boongal Formations may correspond

25.text: to the layered olivine cumulate-pyroxene cumulate-dolerite sill described by Cowley

26.text: (1979: see Figure 4) from a site 5 km along strike to the east.  The NE-most magnetic

27.text: unit corresponds to a mapped layered pyroxenite-gabbro sill within the top part of the

28.text: Pyradie.  This sill may contain a somewhat cryptic serpentinised olivine-rich layer or

29.text: the magnetic response may be due to magnetite within the upper fractionated gabbro.

31.text: Brief field checking of the mapped metakomatiite failed to find any olivine-rich rocks

32.text: similar to those further west.  The most MgO rocks sampled contain 14 and 16.2 %

33.text: MgO (hydrous; see Appendix 1) and have moderate CaO (6.7 and 7.8% respectively),

34.text: Cr (1410 and 925 ppm) and Ni (517 and 762 ppm).  Their compositions suggest that

35.text: these were originally pyroxenitic rocks.  Other rocks samples are low magnesian

text:
Clearly, however, other magnetic units are present within the sequence.  The dolerite 
 sill shown on the contact between the Hardy and Boongal Formations may correspond 
 to the layered olivine cumulate-pyroxene cumulate-dolerite sill described by Cowley 
 (1979: see Figure 4) from a site 5 km along strike to the east.  The NE-most magnetic 
 unit corresponds to a mapped layered pyroxenite-gabbro sill within the top part of the 
 Pyradie.  This sill may contain a somewhat cryptic serpentinised olivine-rich layer or 
 the magnetic response may be due to magnetite within the upper fractionated gabbro.   
 Brief field checking of the mapped metakomatiite failed to find any olivine-rich rocks 
 similar to those further west.  The most MgO rocks sampled contain 14 and 16.2 % 
 MgO (hydrous; see Appendix 1) and have moderate CaO (6.7 and 7.8% respectively), 
 Cr (1410 and 925 ppm) and Ni (517 and 762 ppm).  Their compositions suggest that 
 these were originally pyroxenitic rocks.  Other rocks samples are low magnesian

41.text: There is an agreed protocol with Traditional Owners (Eastern Guruma and the

42.text: Innawonga via the Yamatji Land Council) about exploration within the tenement.

43.text: However no ground disturbing activity was undertaken during the reporting period.

text:
6.0  HERITAGE AND GROUND-DISTURBING CLEARANCES 
 There is an agreed protocol with Traditional Owners (Eastern Guruma and the 
 Innawonga via the Yamatji Land Council) about exploration within the tenement.  
 However no ground disturbing activity was undertaken during the reporting period.
